2010 at 5:29 PM, Berin <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
> I've seen in a =
few places that if an assumption fails, the test automatically passes. =A0I=
 then ran into the test case that confirms that action. =A0Coming from the =
aspect that I want to have confidence that my code and tests are functionin=
g properly, I honestly think that is the wrong action.
>
> If an assumption=
 is violated then it should be either a failure or at best ignored. =A0To s=
ay the test passes because something failed is like saying you don't have a=
 cavity because the dentist doesn't have the right tool. =A0You don't know =
one way or the other, and the test won't be able to run properly when the a=
ssumption is violated.
>
> It's partly that reason that I don't use assumpt=
ions to begin with. =A0If there needs to be a certain precondition to the t=
est passing, I will add those assertions before I perform the action that n=
eeds to be tested. =A0To me, it is a failure if the test could not be set u=
p properly.
>
> If you want something a little softer, then I recommend tha=
t a failed assumption is equivalent to the @Ignore annotation. =A0You'll se=
e in the summary that X number of tests were run, Y number of tests ignored=
, and Z number of tests failed. =A0Although, for ignored tests I'd like to =
see what the reason was (failed assumption or manually ignored through the =
attribute).
>
> Making a test pass because of a failed assumption gives you=
 a false sense of security about your code. =A0What is happening is that th=
e test just wasn't run, and there may be a legitimate problem hiding. =A0To=
 me that is the most dangerous part of that solution. =A0I'd rather get the=
 bad news straight than trust faulty information.

> Am I making sense?
